author: undying1200
content:
There is an actual shortage right now in Tether products preventing the true value of ETH to be realized in the market. The issue is there is not enough supply of leveraged Fiat to accommodate current demand. Because of this there are other avenues to aquire ETH that are being implemented through mining.

Moving to POS removes this acquisition channel and does not provide a likewise method to increase exposure when all other methods have been exhausted. To those that do not understand the dynamics of POW mining and the leverage it provides in acquiring grade A crypto assets might assume the move by HUT 8 is irrational, but I do argue it is quite rational indeed.

author: undying1200
content:
Imagine if you will what would happen to gold if you created a world wide ban on mining. It is pretty simple and I don't need to explain this further. Likewise you would expect mining operations to begin shutting down and the expansion of mining to halt as this is typically a multi year process. However if it only took 30 days to add additional mining capacity (not typically true for gold mining) how many miners would continue adding capacity up until the ban occurred?

I think this is a good analogy in understanding what is happening and will happen to Ethereum mining going into the merge. As the last of the mineable gold (Ethereum) is acquired, the new Ethereum created post merge will be a small fraction of what was possible pre merge. So to some the addition of hardware in this late stage might seem short sighted, but to others, it is the last chance to obtain what will not be so easily obtainable in the future.
